newsitem.title: UK: Moorfield details Greycoat merger plan.
newsitem.headline: Moorfield details Greycoat merger plan.

text.p: UK property group Moorfield Estates Plc said on Wednesday it had presented a more detailed merger proposal to its larger rival Greycoat Plc.

Moorfield first made an approach to Greycoat earlier this month but it was rejected by Greycoat as being "vague as to value". Greycoat called for Moorfield to provide more detailed proposals so it could consider the plan.
Moorfield said in a statement that the merger would be through an offer by it for the entire ordinary share capital of Greycoat, made up new Moorfield ordinary shares and loan notes.
"The total value of the offer to Greycoat shareholders would be the current net asset value of Greycoat as established by an independent external valuation of its property assets," it said.
The mix between ordinary shares and loan notes "is intended to separate Greycoat shareholders' current investment into two separate interests on a tax effective basis", it added.

Moorfield said the planned loan note would be valued at about 110 million stg. This was estimated on the basis of historic information and set "by reference to the value" of Greycoat's two main assets, Embankment Place and 123 Buckingham Palace Road, net of the value of attributable debt.

The company said the loan notes "would give holders substantially all the economic interest in the Principal properties (present and future) whice are intended to be ring-fenced with a pool of capital losses".

It said the notes would yield "substantially in excess of the current yield on Greycoat ordinary shares" and their redemption value would be equivalent to the net value of the properties on realisation.
The loan notes represent a tax effective means of returning cash to shareholders on the subsequent sale or demerger of the properties, Moorfield said.
The rest of the net asset value would be satisfied in new Moorfield shares and would result in the merger of Greycoat's portfolio, minus the principal properties.

Moorfield said the merger was subject to an independent property valuation of Greycoat's and Moorfield's property assets "with the full co-operation of Greycoat", a limited due diligence excercise on Greycoat and a recommendation to Greycoat shareholders to accept the merger by the Greycoat board.
Moorfield, which said the proposals had been put to Greycoat via financial advisers, said the enlarged portfolio would give enhanced growth prospects for both companies' shareholders.

There would also be savings on overheads, with a full year saving of around 1.5 million stg, Moorfield said, adding that a further announcement on "the progress of discussions with the board of Greycoat will be made in due course".
